description: Archaeological images documenting excavations, finds, and research at the Saxon cemetery and prehistoric sites on Farthing Downs

images.suggested_alt_text: Archaeologist Brian Hope-Taylor examining a human skull during the 1948 Farthing Downs excavations
images.suggested_caption: Brian Hope-Taylor examining skeletal remains during the 1948 excavations at Farthing Downs Saxon cemetery
images.historical_context: Brian Hope-Taylor led the 1948 archaeological excavations at Farthing Downs, which uncovered the Saxon cemetery

images.suggested_alt_text: Illustration of an Anglo-Saxon wooden drinking vessel with decorative metal bands, discovered at Farthing Downs
images.suggested_caption: Painting of a wooden drinking vessel discovered by Wickham Flower at Farthing Downs (courtesy of Surrey Archaeological Society)
images.historical_context: This Anglo-Saxon drinking vessel was among the grave goods discovered during early excavations

images.suggested_alt_text: Information board titled 'The Farthing Down Excavations' detailing the 1948 archaeological discoveries including Saxon graves
images.suggested_caption: Summary of the Farthing Down Excavations describing the discovery of six Saxon graves and the site's long occupation from c.2000 BC
images.historical_context: Documents the 1948 excavations led by Brian Hope-Taylor, detailing six Saxon graves and evidence of occupation from Stone Age to Saxon period

images.suggested_alt_text: Farthing Down Research Project information panel with photographs of ongoing archaeological work and excavations
images.suggested_caption: The Farthing Down Research Project (Greater London SMR) - documenting multi-period archaeological evidence from Neolithic to Saxon times
images.historical_context: Since 2004, the Farthing Down Research Project has studied human activity on the site, re-excavating Saxon barrows and investigating earthworks

images.suggested_alt_text: Archaeological site plan of the Saxon Cemetery at Farthing Downs showing burial locations and earthwork features with 100-metre scale
images.suggested_caption: Plan of the Saxon Cemetery at Farthing Downs showing the location of burials and surrounding earthworks
images.historical_context: At least 16 barrows were constructed forming two discrete cemeteries, the largest lying to the north of the Down

images.suggested_alt_text: Illustration of an Anglo-Saxon iron shield boss discovered at Farthing Down, showing the conical metal dome
images.suggested_caption: Painting of a shield boss discovered on Farthing Down by Wickham Flower (courtesy of Surrey Archaeological Society)
images.historical_context: Shield bosses were typically placed in male warrior burials and are key indicators of Anglo-Saxon military culture

images.suggested_alt_text: Multiple Saxon-era human skulls and skeletal remains displayed on a table for archaeological study
images.suggested_caption: Saxon skeletal remains from Farthing Downs excavations, showing multiple skulls and bones laid out for osteological analysis
images.review_reason: Human remains - verify appropriate for general public display
images.historical_context: The human remains were examined by Professor Wood-Jones of the Royal College of Surgeons

images.suggested_alt_text: In-situ photograph of three Saxon skeletons as discovered during archaeological excavation at Farthing Downs
images.suggested_caption: Three Saxon skeletons in situ during excavation at Farthing Downs, showing burial positions in the chalk soil
images.review_reason: Human remains - verify appropriate for general public display
images.historical_context: The excavations revealed flat graves (not covered by burial mounds), a notable feature of this cemetery

key_figures.name: Brian Hope-Taylor
key_figures.contribution: Directed excavations that discovered six Saxon graves

key_figures.name: Wickham Flower
key_figures.contribution: Discovered artifacts including the drinking vessel and shield boss

notes: This collection documents the rich archaeological heritage of Farthing Downs, including the Saxon cemetery with at least 16 barrows and evidence of human activity spanning from the Neolithic to Anglo-Saxon periods. Two images contain human remains and should be reviewed before public display.
